I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed 
policy-based loan to the Cook Islands for subprogram 2 of the Economic Recovery Support 
Program (ERSP).1 
 
2.  Subprogram 2 will build on subprogram 1, which facilitated infrastructure investment in a 
period  of  constrained  revenue,  leveraged  improvement  in  priority-setting  processes  for 
infrastructure investments, strengthened aspects of public financial management (PFM), and 
raised the policy profile of vulnerability issues.2 Subprogram 2 will further support government 
budget priorities, and will promote public sector reforms and measures that will help protect the 
vulnerable and safeguard the fiscal position of the Cook Islands to promote higher and more 
inclusive economic growth. Subprogram 2 was jointly prepared by representatives from the 
Government of the Cook Islands and the Asian Development Bank (ADB).  
 
II.  THE PROGRAM 
A.  Rationale 
3.  The Cook Islands undertook major public sector and economic reforms in 1995 and 
1996, with ADB support, in response to a financial crisis that had its basis in an expanding 
public sector, a limited private sector, and a rapidly increasing debt burden.3 The reforms 
facilitated annual growth averaging 6.1% of gross domestic product (GDP) from FY1999 to 
FY2004. However, minimal infrastructure investment (influenced by the need to reduce debt), 
the impact of several cyclones, high inflation, and weak public sector performance resulted in a 
subsequent  slowdown.  Reduced  revenue  from  tourism  due  to  the  global  economic  crisis 
contributed to an economic contraction in FY2009.4  
 
4.  Subprogram 1 of the ERSP, approved in October 2009, allowed the government to raise 
capital expenditure in FY2010–FY2012. This provided much-needed economic stimulus through 
support for infrastructure investment and maintenance of public buildings, supporting economic 
growth in FY2010 (0.2%), FY2011 (2.4%), and FY2012 (3.4%). Subprogram 1 also facilitated 
strengthening of infrastructure priority-setting processes, improved broad budgetary resource 
allocations,  allowed  the  preservation  of  the  real  value  of  welfare  payments  to  the  most 
vulnerable through FY2010, leveraged commitment to strengthening the social welfare system, 
and supported greater public access to information.  
 
5.  There  is  potential  for  stronger  economic  performance.  The  tourism  industry—which 
attracts  around  100,000  visitors  annually,  almost  nine  times  the  resident  population—is 
hampered by poor infrastructure. High-quality water supply and sanitation is essential to protect 
the natural environment (the prime tourist attraction of the Cook Islands), as well as being vital 
to the health of the population. Roads, airports, and power infrastructure need upgrading. 
Addressing these constraints is essential to increasing economic growth.

7.  Subprogram 2 will build on the gains of subprogram 1 and directly support economic 
recovery combined with protection of the most vulnerable and the fiscal position. Loan financing 
will help meet the government’s overall financing needs for priority infrastructure. A continued 
rise  in  the  standard  of  infrastructure  sector  governance  is  supported  with  the  addition  of 
complementary  policy  action  on  public  sector  reform.  Fiscal  safeguards  are  reinforced  to 
preserve fiscal sustainability and sustain expansion in capital expenditure, while paying special 
attention to the needs of the vulnerable. The development policy letter and policy matrix for 
subprogram 2 are in Appendixes 3 and 4.  
 
8.  Subprogram 2  strengthens  the  partnership  between  ADB  and  the  Cook  Islands  by 
reinforcing progress in areas where ADB has been active over a period of time—infrastructure, 
PFM, and public sector reform. The focus of subprogram 2 reforms are areas identified in the 
country partnership strategy, 2008–20125 and are anchored in Te Kaveinga Nui, the country's 
long-term  strategic  plan.6 Lessons  identified  during  subprogram 1  implementation—placing 
priority on promoting country ownership and keeping the program manageable, given capacity 
limitations—are reflected in subprogram 2.7 Subprogram 2 supports the government’s reform 
program  in  coordination  with  the  European  Union  and  New  Zealand  (active  development 
partners), and completes the program reform agenda under the ERSP.

implementation of the long-term strategic plan for the development of the Cook Islands. Government of the Cook 
Islands. 2007. Te Kaveinga Nui (Pathway for Sustainable Development in the Cook Islands): Living the Cook 
Islands Vision—A 2020 Challenge. Rarotonga.  
7  The design of subprogram 2 incorporates lessons from subprogram 1 (para. 7) and from policy-based lending in 
the Pacific region and elsewhere. The focus is on a systematic approach to improving policy and planning capacity. 
New structures and processes can erode country ownership and have therefore been avoided. Country ownership 
is facilitated by a program of simple scope and within country capacity. The Economic Recovery Support Program 
as a whole encourages broad participation by being anchored in earlier planning and analytical work, which was 
prepared with the benefit of broad-based engagement. Key sources of lessons are: ADB. 2009. Special Evaluation 
Study: ADB’s Support for Public Sector Reforms in the Pacific: Enhance Results through Ownership, Capacity, and 
Continuity. Manila; ADB. 2001. Special Evaluation Study on Program Lending. Manila; ADB. 1999. Reforms in the 
Pacific: An Assessment of the Asian Development Bank’s Assistance for Reform Programs in the Pacific. Manila.

3 
9.  During preparation of subprogram 1 in 2009, 18 triggers were identified as expected 
prior actions for subprogram 2. Consultation with the government on the evolution of priorities 
and the reform context finalized 17 prior policy actions for subprogram 2 (Appendix 4). The 
functional review of the public service and development of a PFM reform program were not 
envisaged during preparation of subprogram 1. However, they have been included as prior 
policy  actions  as  they  demonstrate  strengthened  government  reform commitment,  and the 
functional  review  directly  supports  output 2,  and  development  of  a  PFM  reform  program 
supports output 4. Three output 2 triggers were adjusted as these were translated into policy 
actions, given changes in priorities and the policy environment, while two output 4 triggers were 
dropped as their priority was judged to be less critical to the effectiveness of the program. 
Details of these changes are set out in paras. 12 and 19. All of the agreed 17 prior policy 
actions have been fully accomplished.  
 
B.  Impact and Outcome 
10.  The ERSP will achieve higher and more inclusive economic growth (ERSP impact), and 
will initiate economic recovery with protection of the vulnerable and the country’s fiscal position 
(ERSP  outcome).  The  impact  of  subprogram 2  will  be  economic  recovery  combined  with 
protection of the most vulnerable and the fiscal position. Subprogram 2 will strengthen priority 
elements  of  the  governance  and  institutional  framework  and  improve  opportunities  for  the 
vulnerable. ADB financing will support the government’s overall budget financing needs, which 
have  increased  as  a  result  of  its  greater  need  for  investment  in  infrastructure  and  public 
buildings. The outcome will be sustainable budget allocations for needed capital investment and 
social protection.  
 
C.  Outputs 
11.  Output 1: Higher capital expenditure by government. Budget support will enable the 
government  to  implement  its  FY2013  development  expenditure  program,  particularly 
infrastructure and capital works, which will generate jobs and business activity and create a 
sustainable base for a higher level of long-term growth driven by the private sector. This was 
also the case with subprogram 1 financing of the FY2010 budget. Policy-based loan funds 
supplement weak public sector capacity so as to leverage use of available investment funds. 
 
12.  Heightened  quality  of  capital  expenditure  was  facilitated  by  the  infrastructure 
prioritization process adopted under subprogram 1.8 Since FY2010, prioritization of projects into 
the infrastructure master plan is undertaken by the infrastructure committee and is endorsed by 
the National Sustainable Development Commission (NSDC).9 This process promotes quality 
projects,  transparent  decision  making,  and  alignment  with  the  National  Sustainable 
Development Plan (NSDP).10 The FY2013 adoption of a capital plan has further strengthened 
the quality of capital expenditure.

13.  Output 2: Priority structural reforms and governance improvements implemented 
across the infrastructure sectors. The 2008 infrastructure governance framework (a set of 
government-initiated  policy  principles  and  actions  designed  to  achieve  sound  governance, 
investment decisions, and operational management in the infrastructure sector) guided the 
identification  of  triggers for  subprogram 2.  However,  the  March  2011  commencement  of  a 
functional review of the public sector meant planned legislative and asset management changes 
(trigger 2.2), and consideration of monopoly ownership and management (triggers 2.3 and 2.4), 
were postponed until after the functional review. The government response to the functional 
review is prioritized in the prior policy actions as this supports achievement of the intended 
output. The cabinet considered the recommendations of the functional review and approved a 
focus on productivity and performance in the public sector and support for the performance 
management process. The cabinet also prioritized phased implementation of recommendations 
on outer islands. The Office of Outer Islands has been established within the Office of the Prime 
Minister and is empowering local governments through legislative reform and capacity building.  
 
14.  Improvements in infrastructure governance have continued under subprogram 2. The 
NSDP 2011–2015 was released in December 2011 and includes infrastructure sector objectives 
and strategies that guide ministerial business plans and budget allocations. In keeping with the 
national gender policy,11 the NSDP has a mainstreamed gender perspective, and equity is one 
of its seven guiding principles. Implementation of the infrastructure master plan, 2007–2012 was 
reviewed in August 2011 to assess progress in meeting infrastructure priorities, as well as to 
offer recommendations on future infrastructure delivery. A renewable electricity chart supports 
NSDP implementation, while the cabinet has approved a water policy standard.  
 
15.  The fiscal implications of infrastructure services are addressed under subprogram 2. The 
government financed an independent economic review of the impact of its existing 3-year 
agreement to underwrite losses on Air New Zealand’s nonstop Los Angeles–Rarotonga and 
Sydney–Rarotonga routes.12 The review assessed the likely performance and profitability of the 
subsidized routes as input to government decisions on future support, or otherwise, for these 
routes.13 The cabinet has considered cost recovery and user charges and agreed in principle to 
applying these charges to provision of water to households and businesses on Rarotonga (the 
tourism center, where 74% of the population is located), and to specific charges in respect of 
sanitation in the environmentally sensitive Muri–Avana lagoon area of Rarotonga.14 For the 
FY2013 budget, the Ministry of Finance and Economic Management (MFEM) developed a 
transparent process for financing community service obligations.15  
 
16.  The government has acted to reduce market impediments that constrain private sector 
operations and/or impose social costs. The Cook Islands has operated an extensive regime of 
price controls covering most basic food items and fuel with the intention of keeping key items 
affordable. These controls can, however, force overall prices up, shifting profit margins between 
items rather than reducing the overall cost of consumer items. The Prices Tribunal revoked

17.  Output  3:  The  most  vulnerable  members  of  the  community  receive  targeted 
support from government. The Cook Islands has one of the most extensive social welfare 
systems in the Pacific region, yet it does not fully meet the needs of the most vulnerable 
people.17 Demographic forecasts indicate the likelihood of increased pressure on the social 
welfare system. In 2010 an independent consultant undertook a review of the social welfare 
system for the government with the objective of recommending how to maintain an affordable 
welfare system that better targets assistance. The government had committed to this review 
under subprogram 1 and released the results publicly. The cabinet established a committee to 
develop, with wide consultation, a response to the report for government consideration.18 This 
emphasis on consultation reflects recognition that social welfare system reforms may have long-
term direct social impacts, including on gender relations. 
 
18.  Direct service provision to the vulnerable is being piloted, with ADB support.19 Home 
care services are being provided to the elderly and disabled through local community-based 
groups. Such support is of particular benefit to women, who comprise an estimated 80% of in-
home caregivers. The performance of the pilot is being monitored and performance against 
outcome and outputs will provide information for the design of social welfare reforms.  
 
19.  Output  4:  Ministry  of  Finance  and  Economic  Management  maintains  fiscal 
responsibility. The economic contraction in FY2009, and the change in government in the 
November 2010 elections, provided strong impetus for improvement of PFM systems. Under 
subprogram 2, the government has increased its commitment to fiscal responsibility. A public 
expenditure and financial accountability (PEFA) assessment,20 which independently assessed 
the strengths and weaknesses in PFM performance, guided the development of the PFM road 
map for FY2012–FY2015. The PEFA performance indicators provide the baseline against which 
PFM reforms are monitored quarterly, with a second PEFA assessment planned by June 2015, 
allowing the system’s improvements to be measured. The first quarterly monitoring report was 
completed  in  February  2012.  These  actions  provide  a  comprehensive  framework  for  PFM 
improvements, and as such replace lower priority subprogram 2 triggers—review of Payments 
on Behalf of the Crown and retaining Standard & Poor’s rating service21—as prior policy actions.  
 
20.  Under subprogram 2, the government continues to meet the principles of responsible 
fiscal management set out in the MFEM Act (Section 23[2][a]) so as to promote sound PFM 
through the budget process.22 The fiscal responsibility ratios, set as part of subprogram 1, are

22.  Output  5:  Ministry  of  Finance  and  Economic  Management  communication  of 
economic and fiscal management initiatives. Implementation of the communications strategy, 
which formed part of subprogram 1, continues to develop local awareness and ownership of the 
government’s  response  to  the  macroeconomic  environment.  Transparency  and  access  to 
information has improved—quarterly financial reviews, PEFA report, PFM roadmap, budget 
papers, and half-yearly fiscal updates are available on the MFEM website. The government is 
highly supportive of consultative policy development and demonstrated this by encouraging 
public submissions to the budget process for FY2013 as well as holding a public economic 
summit, and public consultation during development of the NSDP 2011–2015, the public service

D.  Development Financing Needs 
 
23.  The government has requested a loan of NZ$7,250,000 from ADB’s ordinary capital 
resources to help finance subprogram 2, to be provided as a single tranche on completion of 
prior actions. The loan will have a 15-year term, including a grace period of 3 years, straight line 
repayment  method,  an  annual  interest  rate  determined  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  London 
interbank offered rate (LIBOR)-based lending facility, a commitment charge of 0.15% per year, 
and such other terms and conditions set forth in the draft loan agreement. Based on this, the 
average loan maturity is 9.25 years, and there is no maturity premium payable to ADB. 
 
24.  The loan size was determined after consideration of (i) the estimated impact of the 
global economic crisis and the projected deficit financing requirements for the FY2013 national 
budget,  estimated  at  $7.4  million;  (ii) the  availability  of  additional  funding  from  other 
development partners in the event the government is unable to meet this financial requirement; 
(iii) the  significance  and  complexity  of  the  policy  actions  of  the  ERSP,  and  the  budgetary 
resources and political capital required to implement the program successfully; and (iv) the

25.  Infrastructure  forms  a  significant  component  of  the  government’s  development 
expenditure program—roads, water supply, and renewable energy are current priorities. Recent 
significant projects include upgrading Rarotonga International Airport, expanding Aviatui Port, 
and reconstructing outer island harbors. Project implementation sits with line ministries and 
state-owned enterprises. The capital plan, adopted with the FY2013 budget, increases the 
transparency of capital investment and further enhances sector coordination, and notes that 
annual capital expenditure will average NZ$55 million over FY2012–FY2015.24  
 
26.  Other key development expenditures relate to implementation of the PFM roadmap, 
implementation of reforms arising from the functional review of the public sector, and changes to 
the social welfare system coming out of the review of social welfare. There are also expected to 
be nonfinancial costs in terms of the political capital required to maintain public support to 
successfully implement these reforms. The return will initially be in the form of administrative 
savings as a result of PFM reforms, with administrative savings from public sector reforms being 
likely in 2–3 years as organizational changes show results. Improvements in infrastructure 
governance arrangements should hasten implementation of infrastructure projects and facilitate 
revenue raising from infrastructure services such as water supply. The benefits of social welfare 
reform will be realized through reduced future social welfare expenditures as a targeted system 
takes effect, as well as improvement in the individual financial situation of the most vulnerable.  
 
27.  Implementation of subprogram 1 has been a positive experience for the Cook Islands 
(para. 4). It has allowed for an increase in its capital expenditure and further strengthened 
infrastructure management. Subprogram 1 has permitted a better understanding of capacity 
weaknesses and informed discussion with government on how best to address the impact this 
may  have  on  implementation  of  subprogram 2.  More  broadly,  ADB’s  portfolio  in  the  Cook 
Islands is performing well and progress is being made towards targets in the country partnership 
strategy results framework. The proposed loan size is within the established lending allocation, 
and is included in ADB’s country operations business plan.25  
 
E.  Implementation Arrangements 
28.  The MFEM will be the executing agency, and will oversee policy, legal, and regulatory 
actions, and ensure that the reforms agreed to by the government and ADB are duly carried out. 
The ERSP spans 1 January 2008 to 31 December 2012, with the subprogram 2 implementation 
period running from 1 March 2010 to 31 December 2012. ADB’s grant and technical assistance 
projects have helped the government meet tranche conditions.26 The MFEM will be responsible 
for  overall  implementation  of  subprogram 2,  including  all  policy  actions,  administration  of

29.  The proceeds of the loan will be disbursed to the Cook Islands as the recipient according 
to ADB’s simplified disbursement procedures and related requirements for policy-based loans. 
The proceeds will be used to finance items produced and procured in ADB member countries, 
and items in the list of ineligible items and imports financed by other bilateral and multilateral 
sources are excluded. Loan proceeds disbursed against imports will require a certificate from 
the government stipulating that the value of total imports of the Cook Islands, minus its imports 
from  nonmember  countries,  ineligible  imports,  and  imports  financed  under  other  official 
development assistance, is at least equal to the amount of the loan to be disbursed during a 
particular year. Local currency generated from the proceeds of the loan will be used to support 
public expenditure objectives under the ERSP. 
 
30.  In accordance with the simplified disbursement procedures and related requirements for 
program loans, all goods and services produced and originating in ADB member countries will 
be procured with due consideration to economy and efficiency and in compliance with the 
government’s  standard  public  procedures  and  normal  private  sector  commercial  practices 
acceptable to ADB. Goods commonly traded on the international commodity market will be 
procured according to procedures appropriate to the trade and acceptable to ADB. Before 
withdrawal, the government will nominate a deposit account with the Bank of Cook Islands to 
receive the loan proceeds. The account will be managed, operated, and liquidated according to 
terms satisfactory to ADB. ADB will have the right to audit the use of the loan proceeds, and to 
verify the accuracy of the government’s certification. 
 
III.  DUE DILIGENCE 
 
A.  Economic 
 
31.  The economy is rebuilding slowly from the external shock felt in 2009, with a return to 
growth in FY2010. The envisaged impact of the reforms is a permanent shift to a higher level of 
growth, facilitated by improved government efficiency and an ability to allocate a larger share of 
the budget to nonpersonnel expenditure (improved quality of public expenditure). The faster 
pace of revenue growth, through greater cost recovery and a growing tax base, will enable 
improved government service provision, and welfare reforms will promote equitable growth. The 
impact of these changes will become more pronounced in the medium term. However, based on 
past experience, maintaining strong growth will require active public sector management. The 
benefits will be shared by all, but will be particularly felt by the vulnerable. 
 
32.  Through fiscal prudence, the government is prioritizing macroeconomic stability, and the 
resilience of the economy will be strengthened. A macroeconomic assessment, undertaken by 
ADB staff, replaces an IMF letter of comfort (the Cook Islands is not an IMF member).27  
 
B.  Governance 
 
33.  The government’s ability to implement its budget is integral to the success of the ERSP. 
In 2011, PEFA found that the PFM system is centered on a set of relatively advanced budget 
and financial management rules and structures around a clear legislative framework, and the 
rules are well documented. Compliance with these rules and processes in many areas is high, 
while in others, limited capacities constrain the government’s ability to implement processes 
                                                
27 Macroeconomic Assessment (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2). While the external 
review and advice typically received through an IMF Article IV mission is not available, the PEFA process and 
government contracting of Standard & Poor’s rating services provide external scrutiny of economic management.

9 
efficiently. The subsequent PFM reform plan resources the updating of annual accounts and 
targets June 2013 for all the annual audited accounts to be updated. 
 
34.  More broadly, the performance of the public sector as a whole is constrained by weak 
capacity and a fragmented structure. However, actions to improve functional arrangements and 
the legislative environment, supplement capacity, and better manage the performance of state-
owned  enterprises  can  be  expected  to  show  improvements.  Recent  political  stability  has 
enabled commencement of needed governance reforms. It has also seen increased efforts to 
promote transparency as well as consultation and participation by all stakeholders.28 
 
35.  ADB’s  Anticorruption  Policy  (1998,  as  amended  to  date)  was  explained  to,  and 
discussed  with,  the  government  and  the  MFEM.  Consistent  with  its  commitment  to  good 
governance, accountability, and transparency, ADB reserves the right to investigate, directly or 
through its agents, any alleged corrupt, fraudulent, collusive or coercive practices relating to the 
program.  To  support  these  efforts,  relevant  provisions  of  ADB’s  Anticorruption  Policy  are 
included in the loan agreement. These measures will complement the actions under way to 
improve financial accountability and anticorruption measures, which are being put in place by 
the government with the support of its development partners.  
 
C.  Poverty and Social 
 
36.  Although the Cook Islands has the highest GDP per capita of all Pacific developing 
member countries ($9,838 in 2011), vulnerable groups can experience hardship. Women have 
relatively restricted opportunities for economic and political participation and a generally lower 
earning capacity, and are impacted by subtle gender bias. Policy actions have been selected to 
promote poverty reduction and social development, and these form part of the government’s 
own policy agenda set out in the NSDP (footnote 6). Policy actions that directly target the 
vulnerable will disproportionally benefit women, who are overrepresented among the vulnerable 
and bear the burden of infirm family members.29 
 
37.  Beyond the general benefits from increased economic growth and new private sector job 
opportunities,  several  actions  provide  direct  social  and  gender  benefits:  (i) the  NSDP  has 
mainstreamed  gender  issues,  as  required  by  the  national  policy  on  gender  equality 
(footnote 11); (ii) underfunding of selected infrastructure services, and resultant nonexistent or 
poor quality services, is being addressed through consideration and implementation of user 
charges, which include social considerations to ensure vulnerable groups are able to access 
these  essential  services;  (iii)   use  of  a  standard  approach  to  funding  community  service 
obligations  will  enable  support  for  access  to  such  social  services  to  be  better  targeted; 
(iv)  removal of price controls on grocery and laundry products should quickly provide for a 
greater choice of products (of various qualities and prices); (v) vulnerable members of the 
community will specifically benefit from home support services to the elderly and disabled; 
A
(vi)  review of social welfare benefits has the objective of improving targeting; and (vii) improved  p
p
community outreach and engagement will engender community participation and feedback in  en
d
policy design, and will support the direct involvement of women in decision making.  ix
 4
   
 
9

from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2). 
29 As of December 2011, women formed 82% of the recipients of welfare payments for the destitute and care givers.

10 
D.  Safeguards 
 
38.  In compliance with ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement (2009), subprogram 2 is classified 
category C,  with  no  significant  adverse  environmental  impacts  identified.  No  involuntary 
resettlement or impact on indigenous people is expected.  
 
E.  Risks and Mitigating Measures 
 
39.  The potential benefits from ameliorating the impacts of the global economic crisis and 
providing a solid foundation for future growth through structural and governance initiatives are 
considered to outweigh the risks.30 Indeed, the costs of inaction could be substantial, i.e., a 
continued low growth rate, with implications for the government’s ability to fund basic social 
services  and  address  environmental  concerns.  The  following  are  major  risks:  (i) negative 
external  shocks  damage  the  economy,  (ii) parliamentary  and  community  support  for  the 
government’s economic management weakens, (iii) government capacity to implement reform 
program  is  insufficient,  and  (iv) the  government  fails  to  prioritize  capital  works  based  on 
economic  returns.  These  will  be  mitigated  by  support  from  development  partners  for  the 
government’s fiscal consolidation efforts, including elements of subprogram 2 and the use of its 
loan  funds  to  supplement  capacity,  continuing  the  infrastructure  prioritization  process,  and 
implementing a communications and engagement strategy. 
 
IV.  ASSURANCE 
 
40.  The government has assured ADB that implementation of the ERSP shall conform to all 
applicable  ADB  policies  including  those  concerning  anticorruption  measures,  safeguards, 
gender, procurement, consulting services, and disbursement as described in detail in the loan 
documents.  Indicators  and  benchmark  levels  to  monitor  the  outputs  and  outcome  of 
subprogram 2 will be developed by the NSDC to align with its own ongoing monitoring of NSDP 
implementation, but will be inclusive of those contained in the design and monitoring framework 
for the ERSP and for subprogram 2.  
 
V.  RECOMMENDATION 
 
41.  I am satisfied that the proposed policy-based loan would comply with the Articles of 
Agreement of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and, acting in the absence of the President, 
under the provisions of Article 35.1 of the Articles of Agreement of ADB, I recommend that the 
Board approve the loan of NZ$7,250,000 to the Cook Islands for subprogram 2 of the Economic 
Recovery  Support  Program,  from  ADB’s  ordinary  capital  resources,  with  interest  to  be 
determined in accordance with ADB’s London interbank offered rate (LIBOR)-based lending 
facility; for a term of 15 years, including a grace period of 3 years; and such other terms and 
conditions as are substantially in accordance with those set forth in the draft loan agreement 
presented to the Board. 
 
 
Bindu N. Lohani 
Vice-President
